SP.P: Pardon mee Madame, I learned of my Lord, to lende nothing without securitie and pawnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: T'is not monie (Manasses) but counsell and furtherance that we desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Good counsell is worth good monie, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: Thou shalt be well considered; there's twentie Crownes in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Nay Madame, this hand's like a fellow, it takes euerie thing in iest; if you be in earnest, let me feele it heere: So Ladie, now betwixt earnest and iest, if your Will be readie drawne, be∣fore your friend deliuer'd as your deed, and put me in trust to ex∣ecute it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: Tak't, in a word this honest Shepheard, and thy Lordes daughter Madame Mopsa, are man and wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Man, an woman perhaps; but not man and wife: for though most women haue a wil to be Ladies, like my Lords wife; yet euerie Ladie haue not witte to be a wife, as my Lordes Daughter. But what good can I doe in this?

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: O verie much: for though they be man and wife by oath and protestation, the chiefest ceremonie of all; namelie Mariadge, is yet vnperformed, and hearing that you haue tane orders.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: That I haue: I haue tane order for the making away of a hundred Maidenheads in my time, and not so few: but I am in in the minde of you now, these two Beagles, Dorus and Mops, haue run themselues breathlesse in the chase of loue, you would ha me couple'm vp in the leases of Matrimonie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: You are in the right.

SP.SPEAKER: Manass.
SP.P: And you in the wrong, Ile keepe your ieast, but in any case take backe againe your earnest: ile not purchase my Lords displeasure with your gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisan.
SP.P: Thy Lord shall neuer know't.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Oh sir! though my M. hath but bad eyes, he hath excee∣ding long eares: and though a Forrayner may play with a Citi∣zens wooden Dagger, I would not wish any to iest with a Cour∣tiers steeld Sword; tis seldome drawne but it drawes blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: Tush man, be not so timerous, my credit shall countenance thee: bee not an Asse, make vse of thy time: thy Maisters ser∣uice is no heritage; the world knowes he gettes vnder the Duke, thou art a foole, and thou wilt loose vnder him: there's a hundred Crownes for thee; tush man, thy betters will straine curtsey with aleagence for a bribe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mana.
SP.P: Madam, could you to euery one of these Crownes giue me a Kingdome,

SP.SPEAKER: Lisan.
SP.P: What then?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
Lisa.
SP.P: Soone in the euening at Adonis Chapell. Art resolute?

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.P: As your Adamant: thinke you t'was feare made me keepe out? no t'was hope of these flattering sweete lipt drabs, I feare to marrie my Ladyes daughter? no nor to go to bed with her neither. Why, I haue counterfaited his hand & seale. He has been content with mee, to come nearer to him, at his entertainment of the last Embassadour, when he was heat with drinking of healthes. As I led him to his Chamber, I nimde his Chayne, and drew his Purse, and next morning perswaded him he lost it in the great Cham∣ber at the Reuels. He puts mee in trust with his whole estate: he buyes Maners, I purchase Farmes: he buildes houses, I plucke downe Churches: he gets of the Duke, and I of the Commons: he beggers the Court, and I begger the whole Countrey.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: These are notable knauish courses. What breeding hast had?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Verie good breeding Sir: My great Graundfather was a Rat-catcher, my Grandsier a Hangman, my Father a Promooter, and my selfe an Informer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: Thou wert a Knaue by inheritaunce.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P:
And by education too: but Bawdie Informations gro∣wing stale, I gaue vp my cloake to a Broker, and crept into credite for a Gowne, and of Manasses a penurious Informer, I turned
Coppie, & became Manasses, a most, precise, & illiterate expositor.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: Were you a Reader then?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: And a Writer too Bullie; I set some of my Parishioners Wiues such Coppies, as their Husbands might cast their cappes at it, but could neuer come neare.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: But and you vsde such a high and eleuate stile, your audi∣tories low and humble vnderstandings should neuer crall ouer't.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Tush I could fashion the bodie, of my discourse fit to the eare of my auditorre: for to cast Eloquence amongst a companie of Stinctards, is all one as if a man should scatter Pearle amongst the hoggish animals ecliped Swine: no I had paraphrasticall ad∣monitions of all sortes; Some against couetous Landlordes, and that would I squirt awongst beggerlie Tennants: Some against Vsurers, and that would I throw in at Prison Grates amongst prodigall Banqeoutes: Some against the pride of the Court, and that honies the eare of the Citizen: Some against the fraude of the Citie, and that's Cake and Cheese to the Countrie: Some against Protestants, and that's plumpes the lasie Catholicke a∣gainst Papist and Protestant, and that fattens the rancke witted Puritand, against Papist, Puritand, and Protestant; and that tickles the eare of the luxur ous Atheist.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: Why you neuer light vpon anie Atheistes, doe you?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Oh verie manie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisan.
SP.P: In the Countrie perhaps, and the out-skirtes of the citie?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: In the verie boosome of the Citie: and by your leaue, heere and there one in the Court too: But wee fit 'em all; for in deed wee wandering Lightes, haue (as other tradesmen haue) Commodities of all sortes, and prises.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: How doe they come by them?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: As manie doe by Offices, steale into them ere the Duke be aware of 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: Some buy'em at Booke-sellers stalles; but the best they bespeake of Poets.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: Mee thinkes Poets of all men, should not edifie, they are so enuious.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P:
One to another, to no bodie else: a proud Poet is for all the world like a Puncke in request, couetous of manie Cliantes, when she hath more then she can handsomely play off: You
shall haue some Poet (Apolloes Vicar, especially) write you a comi∣call, Pastorall, Tragicall, Musicall historie in prose, will make the auditors eyes runne a water like so many waterspouts: I had one of them my selfe, and your eares be in case, Ile giue you a taste on't; his argument was fet out of the Poem called, The lost sheepe: and thus it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: Pre'thee be briefe?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Nay peace, and it were in place where you might wake, the best men in the parish, for commonlie they sleepe the begin∣ning, because they loue not deuision: but to the lost Sheepe. Beloud, you must imagine this Sheepe was a Sheepe, a lost Sheepe; a Sheepe out a the way: but my deare flocke and louing Sheepe, whom like a carefull Shepheard, I haue gathered together with the whistle or pipe, as it were of mine eloquence, into this sold of peacefull Communitie; Doe not you stray doe not you flie out, doe not you wander, doe not you loose your selues; but like kinde Sheepe, and valiant Rams: I speake to you the better part and head of my flocke. As I say, you shall see the valiant Rammes turne all their hornes together, and appose themselues against the Woolfe, the hungrie Woolfe, the gredie Woolfe, the Lams-de∣uowring Woolfe, the Woolfe of all Woolfes, to defende their Eawes and young ones. Durst you say all your heades together, and with the hornes of your Manhood defende your families, your owne wiues, and your neighbours children: Was not this stinging geere?

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: A good Sheepish admonition.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: The fitter for my Audience: while you liue, haue a eare to fitte your Audience.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: Thou speak'st like a Christian: prethee what Religion art of?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: How manie souer I make vse of, Ile answere with Piauano Orllotto the Italian: I professe the Dukes onely.

SP.SPEAKER: Demet.
SP.P: What's his reason for that?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: A very sound reason: for sayes hee, I came Raw into the world, and I would not willinglie go rosted out, so close vp the stomacke of your Discourse with that dry answere, and euey man about his businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: You'le be mindfull of to morrow-night.

SP.SPEAKER: Man
SP.P: As your Lawyer of the Tearme, or your Landlord of the Quarter day.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: Why so: the mettle I must forge my plot on, lies a war∣ming in the furnace of my braine; and I must fashion it Instantly, for feare it burst the heat. Giue my conceit way, for heere comes one must helpe to proportion it.

SP.SPEAKER: Damet.
SP.P: How now Demetrius, what winde hath blowne vp this storme of melancholie, thy countenaunce was not wont to be thus cloudie? Whence proceedes this sodaine alteration?

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: From mine owne hard fortune my Lord, that my ill-stard natiuitie should continue thus opposite.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Art crost in a sute at Court? or what's the matter? speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: Ile acquaint your Honor: I hope no other eare ouer∣heares vs, Vnder Dianaes Oke I founde an inscription vpon a stone, which told me, that wealth Aristomeres sometimes brought into Archa lea, had there vnder hid a massie summe of treasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: Vnder Dianaes Oke? Dorus shall haue my daughter Mopsa: no more words on't, and thou louest me Dorus: smother thy golden hops a day or two; thou shalt haue Mopsa, but Ile haue all the Gold, then marie my daughter to some great man, though he be poore, tis the fashion: Ile be Noblie allied what ere it cost me: shalt be my Sonne in law Dorus: haue an eye to the Prin∣cesse, fall close to my daughter Mopsa,
SP.L: Court her and spare not: now begins the sport,
Kisse her, doe kisse her; thou shalt pay sweetly fort:
I can gull you, know what faire words can doe,
I'me an old Knaue, and a young Courtier too.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: So, so; how violently he deuowers his bane, and steales himselfe into the order of Gullerie: mee thinkes I see how be∣twixt hope and feare he sweates in his practise, and like a foolish dreamer, castes how to lay out his wealth before it comes in. So much for him: Now to my Ladie Beautie his wife; and as the Diuell would ha're, heere she comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Miso.
SP.P: Dorus, how now Dorus' What time a day is't with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: What time a day so'ert be with mee, tis sleeping time with my Lord, I'am sure of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mis.
SP.P: Sleeping time Dorus, what dost thou meane by that?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Nay nothing: he is troubld with a kind of maladie cald Iusurectio carnis.

SP.SPEAKER: Miso.
SP.P: How, a dish of Creuices? nay and that be the worst, good enough: I am glad a falles to Fish, for he was giuen to Flesh a late too too bad.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Masse I thought as much, for I saw him go a angling.

SP.SPEAKER: Miso.
SP.P: I hold my Ladiship to some strumpet.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Life, a ielosie; I thinke you are a Witch, t'was so indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Miso.
SP.P: Nay I thought as much: he was wont to kisse mee, and doe all kindnes a man could doe, till he came to the Court; and nowe hee will not lie with mee forsooth: and why? tis the Court fashion. He will not loue mee, and why? tis the Court fa∣shion. I must not come neere him at his downe lying, nor his vprising, ctc. And this be the Court fashion, would I were an ho∣nest woman of the Countrie againe, be Courtiers who list. I, I, Dorus, I tell thee in teares, hee hath not done by mee, as a Hus∣band should doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Tis nothing to mee, I cannot do withall Madam, would I could.

SP.SPEAKER: Mis.
SP.P: Yes marie mayst thou Dorus; thou mayst, and shalt doe withal too and thou wilt: but as thou lookest to enioy my daugh∣ter Mopsa, acquaint mee with the olde Foxes starting hole.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: That's past my cunning: the olde Foxe has more holes then one, to hide's head in: But not to goe long about the bush with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mis.
SP.P: No good Dorus, I do not loue a man should go long about my bush: What is she for a woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
Miso.
SP.P: Manasses wife? marie fire Maister gunner; a Putitane turnd Puncke: Gods my precious. Ile slit her nose, as I am a Ladie will I: is shee the partie you wot on?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Yes fayth Madam, shee is the Mare the man rid on.

SP.SPEAKER: Mis.
SP.P: Ile spoile their sport, sadle my Mule there, haue an eie to the princesse: shalt ha my daughter and be but to spite him withal, faith Fox ile ha you out of your hole, or ile fire you out.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Nay that will doe no good, but for your owne good Ma∣dam, take heed you doe not scold.

SP.SPEAKER: Mise.
SP.P: Why may not a Lady scold Dorus?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Scold, O in no case, twill marre a Ladies beautie cleane, and make her looke as hard fauoured at any ordinarie woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mis.
SP.P: Godamercie for that Dorus, Ile not loose my beautie for twentie on'em: saddle my Mule, bring me my chopping knife, Ile gold the lecherous Goat, and mince his Trull, as small as herbs to the pot. This is not scolding Dorus, is't?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: No this is tollerable.

SP.SPEAKER: Mis.
SP.P: Nay then I care not, saddle my Mule I say, let her pray God her feeling be good, for as I am a Ladie, Ile not leaue her an ele to see withall, and yet I will not scold neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Oh take heed of that at any hand, So, so, so: now it be∣gins to quicken me thinkes, I see alreadie how she runs atilt at the Wenches eies: cals the maid Baud, the woman Whore, and her husband Lecher: and when all comes to all, like an Irish Wolfe, she barkes at her owne shadow; but committing her and her Asse to their wildgoose chase: now to my sweet hart Mopsa, for she's all the blockes last in my eie to slumble on: and God blesse my wits, for the foole haunts me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mops.
SP.P: Dorus, where's my Father Dorus?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Your Father, Oh my deare Mopsa?

SP.SPEAKER: Mop.
SP.P: Nay now you flout me?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Flout you? oh the faire heauens, but this ti's for a man to cast away himselfe in violence of passion and extremitie of sighs on a piece of beautie, that cares not for him, but it is the tricks on you all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mop.
SP.P: Trickes, no as god mend me, and I should not haue a hus∣band till I got him with tricks, I should lead apes in hell: but faith tell me, dost thou loue me Dorus?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Doe I loue you quoth ye, It cuts my very heart strings, doe I loue you? why tis the onely marke my Inqeuors she or at.

SP.SPEAKER: Mop.
SP.P: If thou dost not hit the marke, then thou'rt a very bung∣ler: but where is my Father?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Why I haue sent him and your mother out of the way of purpose, and appointed Manasses to meet vs this euening at Ado∣nis Chappell in the Amasons apparell, to marrie vs: I thinke this are signes I loue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mop.
SP.P: I but you ieast, I doubt you will not marrie me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Will you meere me there?

SP.SPEAKER: Mop.
SP.P: As I am a Virgin I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor,
SP.P: And come with an intent to marrie me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mop.
SP.P: As I hope to be a wife I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: You must take heed you keepe our purpose close,

SP.SPEAKER: Mop.
SP.P: As I did the losse of my Maydenhead.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Why haue you lost it then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mop.
SP.P: Many a deere day agoe, yet I told Nobody on't but my Mother and our Horsekeeper, and they say I am nere the worse mayd for that, and I can keepe my owne counsell, as I hope I shal; but will you meet me soone?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Iust in the mid-way, as Tilters doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mop.
SP.P: Ile goe afore and stay, but doe not deceiue me, and you doe, Ile shew my Fathers Horsekeeper all as God mend me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: So tria sequntur tria, now am I rid of a triumuirie of fooles,
and by there absence haue won a free accesle to an escape.
If my Lisanders hope proue like to this,
This night shall Crowne vs Monarchers of our ble.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.P: No more of these delayes sweet Madam, your loue hath broken day oft with my expectance, I dare giue it trust no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: I confesse it my Liege, and like a spent Deare, not able to maintaine longer flight, I cast my selfe downe breathlesse at your loues mercie: yet I beseech your Maiestie, let not your eager de∣sires, practise any present violence vpon my yeelding chastitie: twas onely possession of my loue you had in chace, which with conuenent time & place purchased, I put your grace in full pos∣session of.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.P:
Although thy Breath be neuer but Musicall, yet it neuer taught the string of true happines till now: and to approue thy
heart sets hand to thy word, appoint the time.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: Then this present euening (and yet my Virgin blood, and ashamd to consent to the betraying of my modestie) meete me at Adonis bower, where ile make tender of subdued chastetie to your high Maiestie, as my first & most victoriuos conquerour.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.P: By my Imperiall Globe, and hope of those Ioyes, thy presence shall bring to inrich me with, ile meete thee, and make thee Queene ouer the most submisse Captiue that euer loue tooke prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: If you deceiue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Not except warme life,
Deceiue my voice of their innatiue heate.
Then hast slow time, exchange thy leaden sleete,
For Hormes wings till I my faire hopes meete.
But lockt once in the armes of my delight,
Cloth all the world in an eternall night.
And steed of morning when the Sunne should rise,
They shall see two in my Zelmanes eies.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: So farewell thought I, I haue prepar'd you a Zelmanes answerable to your expectation.
Then triumph in thy will, and let thy thoughts
Proclaime a lubilee: my teeming hope:
Are now deliuered of a gratious birth,
Which I haue Christened, opportunitie.
Vnto whose shrine in honour of this day,
My thoughts shall hold a monthly sacrifice,
Loue graunt Demetrius, meete the like successe,
Our paines are crownd with double happinesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Onely our disguises hold firme, but all other attempts meete vntimely deathes, euen in their cradles.

SP.SPEAKER: Amin.
SP.P: What and wee should acquaint the Ladies with our intents.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P:
Twould argue a kind of cowardise in out wits, that ha such suspectles admittance to there presence, as this disguise hath purchased vs, we should not haue that abilitie of inuenture to en∣tangle'em
in their owne securitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Amint.
SP.P: Well howsoeuer, we must not dwell long determi∣ning for the libertie of stay with Dametas, who out of his couetous disposition in detaining our reward, allowed vs the eldest day of our licent abode at Court, is run out.

SP.SPEAKER: Juli.
SP.P: Tis very true, and for my part, Ile rather go home with a priuate repulse, then managing any vnlikely attempt, become sufferer vnder a publike disgrace.

SP.SPEAKER: Ami
SP.P: Thats my very thought, yet that our second ariuall bee not altogether empty of imploiment, lets practise something vpon Dametas, and acquaint the world with his coward basenes; in which, he not only detracts from his masters bountie, but looke how as Conduit head or master-spring that is poisoned, doth his best, to enfect the whole bodie of the court, with the leprosie of his couetousnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Juli.
SP.P: Theres no action of his begetting can be said to be truely honourable.

SP.SPEAKER: Ami.
SP.P: How can they when there Father's a mungrell, the Duke out of his honourable bountie commaunded him to reward our trauailes with 200. Crownes: and now after two moneths atten∣dance, and enforst delayes: In which time an ordenarie petitioner might haue spent the vasew of the reward, he packes vs off with 50. Crownes, his excuse being that his master hath forgot vs, and what he doth, is of his owne bountie, as if the Moone should brag she gaue the world light, when al the luster she hath, comes from the heat of the Sunne.

SP.SPEAKER: Juli.
SP.P: Should his villanies be suffered to prosper, they would grow to such height, as the Dukes authoritie should ha much trouble to prune them.

SP.SPEAKER: Ami.
SP.P: To preuent which, his maiestie shall haue priuate note of it, knew we in whose trust to conduct it.

SP.SPEAKER: Iuli.
SP.P: Tis an Office verie few dare vndertake, he is so riueted to the Dukes good opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Amt.
SP.P: Lyes there no iarre twixt none of the Nobilitie and him, what say you Zelmanes?

SP.SPEAKER: Juli.
SP.P: The gallant, Amason: you could not ha cast your choyce fitter, for her honorable minde maintaines deadly feud against his bace proceedinges: and heere she comes, attended by Dametas seruant, lets waite on oportunitie.

SP.SPEAKER: De.
SP.P: Lisander.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: Demetrius.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulo.
SP.P: Lisander and Demetrius, stand close, of my life we are come to the birth of some notable knauery.

SP.SPEAKER: Amt.
SP.P: How blowes the winds of our hopes?

SP.SPEAKER: Lisand.
SP.P: Fayr to the point of our expectlicion, I haue made away the Duke and the Dutch.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: How made away them? poysond them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: with a confection of loue, which I haue so tempred with fair promices, as theyr minds are in loues heauen already: Ʋidelicet in Adonis bower, wher this euening I haue giuen em my word to meet em; but I haue so cast it, that Manasses shall meete em in my steede.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: Twil be a rare scean of myrth, to hear what costly discours the ile bestow vpon the foole in thy outside.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Do you heare that.

SP.SPEAKER: Ilipo.
SP.P: yes, thanke loue and my eares, but list the conclusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: I haue cleard the way to Violetta, but what order hast thou tane, with thy burbolts: Dameta, Myso, and amorous Mopso.

SP.SPEAKER: Damet.
SP.P: shot em away, at three seuerall markes, yet so conueyd it that in the end they shall all meet at Adonis chappell.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisan.
SP.P: This proiect cannot but bring forth some notable deceipt.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: My hopes should want of thyer will, and it do not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisand.
SP.P: Now we haue made a smooth passage to our escape, how shall conuey our louer out of the Iland.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: I haue determined of that sir, and better to effect, my boy this time hast cast such a bait of knauery to the two Captaines, Kala∣der and Philinax, as we may passe without suspition.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisan.
SP.P: But how for transportation.

SP.SPEAKER: De.
SP.P: I am furnisht of that to, you remember the two Lacedemou intelligencers

SP.SPEAKER: Ilip.
SP.P: Now what of vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Hold my life, we shall be put in this scean of gullery.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisan.
SP.P: Oh in any case.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: For the loue of Cupid do, iniquiris past, lets take our en∣trance, and passe ouer the stage like mues, to furnish out a showe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisan.
SP.P:
And see occasion like a kind wench presents em in the ve∣ry instant my honest friends welcome, haue you not your dispatch
with a letter to Lacedemon.

SP.SPEAKER: Amt.
SP.P: Madam we haue, and stay onely to take our leaues of your Ladiship, and know what seruice your honor will command.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisan.
SP.P: you haue my thankes, for the truth is, I must commit bu∣sinesse of much import vnto your trust, and to preuent much cir∣cumstances take my word, you are not ignorant of the Kings gene∣rall challenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: About his daughters.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: you vnderstand me, with these few crowns receiue my mind which is to conuey the 2, ladies whome we in these disguises haue woon to Lacedemon,

SP.SPEAKER: Amt.
SP.P: were we but confirmd of your of estates.

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.P: wele giue your sufficient assurance of that and the princesses themselues shall confirme it.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio,
SP.P: we craue no better madam, but shall we not ha yours ho∣nors company.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: No: hauing brought them abord, weele make returne to the Duke, to let him vnderstand we stole not our prizes but woon them manfully at the point of wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Amt.
SP.P: A noble resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: His foile wil appeare the more palpable, and your conquest the more applausable, where shall we receiue the Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: Be that our care, but on your liues be heedful of your safe ties.

SP.SPEAKER: Amt,
SP.P: More then of our own my lord,

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: Inough whilst you attend weele to the Duke, and play all guls or none.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: All Guls indeed since you had follies whip,
No guls, to all guls, fooles loue fellowship.

SP.SPEAKER: miso.
SP.P: Looke well to mine Asse ther, lord how I sweat with anger; this sames the house sure, and now like a wise Lady let me count my hurts, and see how I shal be reuengd: it shalbe so, ile haue em both carted, and manasses shal go afore like a whifler and make way with his horns, where be these whores: open the dore, wher be these pan ders: O that I were not a lady: I could scold like a butter-whore,

SP.SPEAKER: wife.
SP.P: whose there a gods name, lord for his mercy is the woman mad.

SP.SPEAKER: miso:
SP.P: yes I thanke ye fort: horn mad, wheres your companion whetes the old leacherous goat my husband, open the doore I say.

SP.SPEAKER: wife.
SP.P: Iesus for thy mercie sake madam, what do I want.

SP.SPEAKER: Miso.
SP.P: what do I want, the chiefe implement a woman shold haue I want that as a woman cannot be without, I mean my husband, I want.

SP.SPEAKER: wife,
SP.P: your husband, I sawe him not as I am an honest woman.

SP.SPEAKER: mi.
SP.P: not as you are an honest, so I think, but as you are an arrant whore you did, you must haue your Creuishes with a pox cannot Citty Maunchet and fresh cod-serue your turne, but you must haue Court cake-bread and Creuishes with a vengeance, but come giue me my husband, or ile haue him out of the flesh on thee, and yet I will not scold neither.

SP.SPEAKER: wife
SP.P: Pray Madam ha patience: what should your husband do here

SP.SPEAKER: mis.
SP.P: That which he should do at home with his wife, and he were worth his eares.

SP.SPEAKER: wife,
SP.P: Lady I protest I do not know him,

SP.SPEAKER: miso.
SP.P: Not know him thou liest in euery vaine ith hart thou lyest, thou knowest him, and as Adam knew Eue thou knowest him, hee hath bene as inward with thee, as euer he was with me, he hath by his own confession he hath, & thou deniest it, thou liest in thy throat like a Puritanicall whore as thou art, O that I were a butter-whore for an houre I might scold alittle.

SP.SPEAKER: wife
SP.P: Madam they are no honest men that bring these tales to you

SP.SPEAKER: mis.
SP.P: Men bring tales to me, I defie thee in thy guts, I defie thee, men bring tales to me, thou takest me to be one of thine own church dost: they are no honest men that bring tales to thee and ha wiues of their own, and my husbands one of them, go thy waies now.

SP.SPEAKER: wife.
SP.P: I beseech you madam do but heare me.

SP.SPEAKER: mis,
SP.P: Hear thee, I haue heard too much of thee, too too much too much, wheres my husband, bring forth my husband, ile teach him to put a difference betwixt Ioan and my ladie I hold him ten pound ont, and yet I wil not scold neither, and I had bin an old hag past tea ming as his whore is a puritan, it had bid somwhat, but being a wo¦man of Gods making, and a ladie of his own, and wearing mine own haire which is much in a ladie of my standing I can tel you, to vse me thus, flesh and blood canot induer, let me come in, open the dore let me come in, O that I were anie vile thing in the world but a la∣die that I might scold a little.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Kalander and philanax Demet, boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: So so, so, take your places, for the same bald pated oke is the stage, where ye shall see the part of a doting foole performd by an old man and a young wench,
SP.L: Do worshipfull Dametas,
The same man,
Hath he no fellow acters in his most lamentable, commical, histori∣call, tragicall, musicall, pastoriall.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy
SP.P: None that require any mouthing but his Asse and himselfe, marry then he has Signer Mattocke, a very sharpe sastyricall humo∣tist, and Mounser le spade, but he goes somewhat more bluntly to his businesse, yet heele serue for mutes, and as good as the best to furnish out the stage.

SP.SPEAKER: Kal,
SP.P: But dares Dorus being but Dametus seruant so abuse his mad maister thus grosely.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy
SP.P: O Lord Sir, their ha ben seruing men haue done their Mai∣sters farre greater abuse, yet had their wiues conceald it, their eares should neuer haue bin acquainted with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Is that a fashion in request.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy
SP.P: Altogither Ile assure you, but obedience Gentleman the sean beginnes.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Damet as with mattocke and spade

SP.SPEAKER: kal.
SP.L: Pray God it be good he staies so long,
Ridiculous enough, and good enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Dame.
SP.P: So, stand Asse, stand gentle Asse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ka.
SP.P: What countreimen is his Asse he speakes so familiarly to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy
SP.P: Ath Citty breede, marrie he picks vp his lyuing ath burs and nettles that grow about the Court gate.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam.
SP.P: be in readines good mattocke, play thy part sweet spade, let me see Dianaes oke? I held Dianaes oke deuine, true pure gold honest, Dorus, fortunate Dametas.

SP.SPEAKER: Ka.
SP.P: An excellent come dyan, what life he puts into his part.

SP.SPEAKER: Da.
SP.P: So, by thy leaue stone, by thy patience honest stone, the very grauell sauours of treasure, this sames the bed chamber of my Lady Pecunia, and see, see some of her golden haires, more, more, more yet diuine tree, pure gold, honest Dorus, fortunate Demetrius, soft¦ly, softly, not to fast, let me not deuoure my content too greedily least like a cormorant I take a surfet ont.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Oh take heed of that maister in anie case.

SP.SPEAKER: da.
SP.P:
Pure mettle, excellent gold: but let me see nowe, I shall by computation haue some three millions of them, I some three or foure millions, how shall I imploy em to make the most profit of
em.

SP.SPEAKER: da.
SP.P: That would be knowne indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: da.
SP.P: Ile put out one million to vse, after the rate af seuen score to the hundreth: and yet I wnot, no fie, for then you wil ha my humor brought ath stage for a vserer; to preuent with scandalous report, ile put it into my Scribe-maiors hand, and he shall deale for mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Kal:
SP.P: Theres is a simple cloake to couer his villany.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil:
SP.P: Tis a very short one,: and passing slite to hide his knauerie.

SP.SPEAKER: boy.
SP.P: it cannot chose but be seene through,

SP.SPEAKER: dam:
SP.P: An other Milion ile lay to bestow in Offices. I wil haue welth or ile rake it out ath kennels else, chimnies ha smoakt for alreadye, and now ile deale vpon sea-cole and salt, now, now, now, it comes, sweet gold, honest Dorus, fortunate Demetrius, deuine gold, how, how, shal I adore thee, O let me do the homage of my knees: now nowe, for the tongue of a Poet, tho I hate poetrie worse then any of the seauen deadly sinnes, I could wish my selfe a Poet for some houre, to write a Poem in the praise of my diuine mistres; and see the verie bed wherein her diuinitie is lodged: happy, happy, thrice

SP.SPEAKER: boy.
SP.P: happie Dametas, now like an oreioid louer, let mee open the sheets of my heauenlie mistris, with reuerence, so with humble re∣uerence, and like a blushing louer that puts out the light ere he pre∣sumes to touch the bed of his loue so let me darken the candles of my bodie, mine eies, and first blesse my hands with touching, next inrich mine ears with hearing, and lastlie make happie my eies with with seeing, and let them convey the ioy downinto the bosome of my thoughts, by degrees, softly by degrees.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi:
SP.P: Did you euer see Asse make such a ceremonious preparation

SP.SPEAKER: dam:
SP.P: be not offended sweet mistris that I presume to touch.

SP.SPEAKER: phil:
SP.P: a fooles head of your owne,

SP.SPEAKER: Kal:
SP.P: Has a bin at any cost of al this inuocate for a coxcomb and a bel.

SP.SPEAKER: phil:
SP.P: beshrow my iudgement but he desetues it,

SP.SPEAKER: boy:
SP.P: And his desert were neere so much, he could but beare away the bel, and so you saie he doth:

SP.SPEAKER: da:
SP.P: A coxcombe and a bel, oh indignity: damnable ok, vile and euil accuest Dorus, vnfortunate Dametas, Diana I tel thee thou art no honest goddes to vse a Gentleman thus. What here a writing, your helpe good spectacles, lend me your helpe good spectacles, some comfortable newes good spectacles:
SP.L: Who hath his hire hath well his labours plast,
Earth thou didst seeke, and store of earth thou hast.
He that vaine hopes pursues for loue of pelfe,
Shall loose his wits and likely finde himselfe,
Then thinke thy paines rewarded well,
Thou broughst the foole, beare backe the bell:
Of other matters what ensues
Adonis bower shall tell the newes,
Villanous poetry, I am made a flat foole by poetry,
But though I can do em no futther disgrace, my fatall curse,
a Wronged gentlemans fatall curse dwell euer vpon them, Diana
Heere me, and let my words finde gratious acceptance.

SP.SPEAKER: Kal.
SP.P: Hide your heads, the terrible curse comes like a ston vpon you

SP.SPEAKER: Da.
SP.L: Rancor, spite, mallice, hate, and all disasters,
Strengthen my faith against all portastors.
May their intents tho pure as christall glasses,
Be counted falts and capitall trespasses,
O may their liues and labourd industrie,
Though worthy of Apolloes plaud it be
The cleerest thought in loyalty excelling
Be by some Dor presented for libelling,
when they haue writ a seeine in which their braines,
Haue dropt there deerest sweets, and their swoln vaines,
Emptied their Cundits of their purest spirit,
As they stand gaping to receiue their merrit,
In sted of plaudities their chiefest blisses
Let their desarts be crownd with mewes and hisses:
Behinde each post and at the gallery corners,
Sit empty guls, slight fooles and false informers,
Let some slye Foxe out of discreations embers,
Terme them the lands vnnecessary members,
And like the deere when they haue spent their breath,
to make kings sport let them betorne to death,
Euen by their friends, twold set my thoughts a twanging
Might I but see one of them go to hanging.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Capt.
SP.P: A passing strange curse and no question he has traueld far for some of the rimes,

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Cap.
SP.P: He must trauaile further that finds any rea∣son int,

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cap.
SP.P: No matter for reason theirs rime enough and that be good.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Cap.
SP.P: Som: of it is no better then it should be, or my iudge∣ment deceiues me.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cap.
SP.P:
Sure he had some reason to make this rime,
and a man could pick it out,

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Cap,
SP.P: rather then ile be counted inqui∣sitiue, mine eares shal content themselues with the rimes onely, and leaue the reason to the scanning of poets whom it more neerly con∣cerns.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cap,
SP.P: But wheres the wag that inuited vs to this banquet of mirth shrunke in the wetting?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 cap:
SP.P: tware a rare iest now if whilst the boy kept vs heere in expec¦tation of Dametas gullery his M: had made an escape with the duks daughters,

SP.SPEAKER: 1 cap:
SP.P: that or some knauery else vpon my life, I had the boy in shrowd suspision at the first.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 cap.
SP.P: And this his suddaine and stolne departure, confirmes it cur∣rant

SP.SPEAKER: 2 cap:
SP.P: then we are sped, for in suspisions face,
SP.L: I see some suttle stratagem in chase.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife:
SP.P: Will your lordship beleeue me now: nay and I sait your wor∣ship may swert, tho I haue but a (poore as to say) hole of mine own I hope the spirits haue more denomination ouer me, then to make it a common slaughter house of carnallity where euery iacke may command flesh for his mony,

SP.SPEAKER: miso:
SP.P: No more words sweet woman I confesse I was in the wronge, there is not the hole the Foxe hides his head in: and therefore for the loue of womanhood conceale mine errors, for howsoeuer I complaind tis thy forhed aks, thy temples ha the terrible blow as the say, thy husband is a bad man.

SP.SPEAKER: wife,
SP.P: my hus∣band:

SP.SPEAKER: miso:
SP.P: I, I, good woman thy husband: he is as I say a fleshly member and I fear he hath ouercome the foolish thing my daugh∣ter.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife
SP.P: your daughter ile slit her nose by this light and she wer ten ladies, twas not for nothing my husband said he should meete her this enening at Adonis chappel, but and I come to the godspeed ont, ile tel em ont soundly?

SP.SPEAKER: miso:
SP.P: I do good woman tel em ont, & spare not but in any case do not scold.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife:
SP.P: Why may not a gentlewoman scold in a good case:

SP.SPEAKER: miso:
SP.P: I know not what a gentlewoman do in a good case, but a lady must not in any case:

SP.SPEAKER: Wife:
SP.P: tho I may not scold I may tel em roundly ont I hope,

SP.SPEAKER: miso:
SP.P: that may you do lawe,

SP.SPEAKER: Wife:
SP.P: and ile not be mealely mouthd I warrant em, wil you beare me company to the chappell maddam?

SP.SPEAKER: miso.
SP.P: withall my hart mistris, what Dorus hath giuen me, ile giue my friend, no foole to company.

DIV3.HEAD: Actus quinti, scena prima.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter the duke at adonis bouer
DIV3.L: Farewell bright sunne thou lightner of all eies
thou falst to giue a brighter beame to rise.
Each tree and shrub were tramels of thy haire,
But these are wier, for none but kings to weare,
And my rude tonge striuing to blaze her forth,
Like a bad art seman doth disgrace her worth,
but heeres the place, vpon this christall streame:
Where Citherea did vnyoake her teame
Of siluer doues, to interchange a kisse
With young Adones shall I meete my blisse:
The gentle minits crownd with christall flowers,
Loosing there youthes, are growne vp perfect howers,
To hasten my delight, the bashfull moone
that since her dalliance with Endimior,
Durst neuer walke by day is vnder saile,
In steede of sheetes has spred her siluer vaile,
Each gliding brooke and euery bushy tree
Being tipt with siluer were her liuery,
And the dim night to grace our amorous wars,
Hath stuck nine spheares full of immortall stars,
Insted of pearles the way on which she treads
Is strawd with Christall deu and siluer beades.
She comes, her feete makes musicke with the ground,
And the chast ayre is rauisht with the sound,
My soule flyes forth to meete her: hell my wife,
Her presence like a murtherer driues the life
Out of my pleasure breast, her ielous cie
Enuyes the heauen of my felicity.

SP.SPEAKER: Dut.
SP.P: Zelmane, or my husband life or hate.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.L: What makes old Autum out a bed so late,
that snow should goe a woeing to the sunne
When one arme kisse works her confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Dut.
SP.L: I haue the iest, suspition that keepes
Court in my husbands thoughts, seeing my loue,
Elect this walke, hath brought him after him.

SP.SPEAKER: K.
SP.P: She dogs her fure, and she to shake her off Hath taine some other walke Ile place mine eare in distance of her will.

SP.SPEAKER: Dut.
SP.P: Could I but heare the innocent deliuery of his breath, twold be a second iubile of mirth.

SP.SPEAKER: Da.
SP.P: Heere comes my loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Dut.
SP.L: your loue? Alasse poore Duke,
Your forward hopes will meete a barren spring,
My sunne appears.

SP.SPEAKER: Da.
SP.L: Fie your loue speakes to loude,
Your sunnes eclipst, your date vpon a cloude.

SP.SPEAKER: Dut.
SP.L: See how his armes like precious phenix wings,
Spred to imbrace me.

SP.SPEAKER: Da.
SP.L: Now the Cucko sings,
Those amorous armes do make a golden space
To hug a Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Dut.
SP.P: But ile fill vp the place.

SP.SPEAKER: Da.
SP.L: Those fingers tipt with curious porphery,
Staining Pigmalions matchlesse imagery,
Like amorous twins all of one mother nurst,
Contend in curtesie who should touch me first.

SP.SPEAKER: Dut.
SP.L: should touch me first: their strife is vndertook,
To twine a young bay not a farre stooping oake.

SP.SPEAKER: Da.
SP.L: Young bay, stale lest, that a dry saplesse rinde
should hold young thoughts, and a licentious minde,
Were he but gone now.

SP.SPEAKER: Dut:
SP.L: Were the Duke away,
My hope, had got the better of the day.

SP.SPEAKER: Man:
SP.P: This is Adonis chappell, I wonder they come not, tho I beare a little learning about me, and a few good clothes, I wold not wisham to make Balams asse a me: for though many fooles take no felicity but in wearing good clothes (tho they be none of their own) I haue a further reach in me.

SP.SPEAKER: Da:
SP.P: I could ban my stars.

SP.SPEAKER: Dut:
SP.P: I curse my fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Da:
SP.P: That crosse me thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Dut:
SP.P: Make me vnfortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Da:
SP.P: Alas good lady, how her prety feet labour to finde me.

SP.SPEAKER: dut:
SP.P: that my hopes should meete such blacke euents.

SP.SPEAKER: da:
SP.P: O would the trindly night darken her selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Dut.
SP.L: Would the Moone lose her light,
That in the bosome of some foggy cloud
I might embrace my loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke
SP.L: But night is purblind
To make a Duke a slaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Dut.
SP.L: To make a Dutches
wrastle with amorous passions.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk,
SP.L: life a spleene
Could my rough breath like a tempestious wind,
Blow out heauens candles, leaue the world starke blind,
That it might either haue no eies to see:
Or vse those eies it hath to pleasure me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dut.
SP.P: Or vse those eies it hath to plesure me.

SP.SPEAKER: man.
SP.P: Who woulde ha thought the cold had bene so good a musition: howe it plaies vpon my chappes, and maketh my teeth skippe vp and downe my mouth like a company of virginall Iackes, but I find small musicke in it, and Mopsa should come now I could doe her little good, yet and she were here, she and I would haue about at cob-nut or at che∣ri-pit or somewhat to keep our selues from idlenes, tho she be but a foole, the bables good enough to make sport with all in the darke and that very word hath started her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mop,
SP.P: whose there Manasses.

SP.SPEAKER: man,
SP.P: yes Mopsa.

SP.SPEAKER: mop.
SP.P: plain

SP.SPEAKER: Mop.
SP.P: I might be madam Mopsa in your mouth, good∣man &c. whers Dorus.

SP.SPEAKER: man,
SP.P: why because he wil not be saide to make too much hast to a bad bargaine, he is not come yet,

SP.SPEAKER: mop,
SP.P: not come, a pescod on him, but als one I thought at first he would make but a foole on me.

SP.SPEAKER: man,
SP.P: would you haue him mend Gods wormanship?

SP.SPEAKER: mop,
SP.P: But chose him, since he hath buld me with an vrchin, ile goe fetch Raph our horskeeper, let him that got the calfe keep the cow in a knaues name and he wil, ha you your booke heere.

SP.SPEAKER: man,
SP.P: no matter wench, I can dote wel inough without booke,

SP.SPEAKER: mop.
SP.P: Nay and ye can dote wel inough your selfe, I care for neither of them both, but indeed I loue to haue a thing wel done, for saies my mother, a thinge once wel done, is twice done, and I am in her mind for that vp and downe,

SP.SPEAKER: Dut,
SP.L: Whose with my Lord the Duke, it cannot be,
Mine eie would not conceale such trechery.

SP.SPEAKER: Dut,
SP.L: Tis not the Dutches sure, no it is amarous Ioue,
that seeing Zelmane passionate for loue,
Descends to comfort her, Ioue if there be
A powerful Phebus God of poetry,
In deare remembrance of faire Daphnes rape,
to win my loue, lend me some stranger shape,
Such as your selues haue worne, that when your fame
is sung by poets, they maie cote my name,

SP.SPEAKER: Dut,
SP.P: Sure tis my daughter,

SP.SPEAKER: Duk,
SP.L: Daughter: how her eie
Cuts out new formes, new shapes of iealousie:

SP.SPEAKER: Dut.
SP.L: As sure as death tis she, for see they stand
like amarous twins, intwisted hand in hand,
Breast against breast, and that no ioy be missing,
To heare discourse, their lips keepe time with kissing,
Ile not indurst impatience grow strong,
And tho a prince, tel him he doth thee wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: duk
SP.L: Do preethe do, this sweetens al the rest,
But here would be the elixar of the iest,
if whilst we kept each other at a baie,
A third should come, and beare the hare away.

SP.SPEAKER: dam.
SP.P: villanous poetrie, vnchristian like poetry, I am cozend of my golde by poetrie, robd of my charge by poetrie, made an apparent foole by poetrie vilanous Oke, accurst Dorus, vnfortunat Dametas: whose there my daughter and with Zelmane? a wel-willer to Dorus, a fa∣uorite to poetrie, and therfore enemie to Dametas, come hither mop so, a thy fathers blessing come not neare her: what Mopsa.

SP.SPEAKER: mop.
SP.P: yes, whose there? Dorus.

SP.SPEAKER: dam.
SP.P: Confusion a Dorus, I am thy miserable father, didst not see Hippolita,

SP.SPEAKER: mop.
SP.P: no by my troth not I? Did ye not see Dorus.

SP.SPEAKER: dam.
SP.P: Poxe of dorus I am vndone madam and thou telst mee not of Hipolita,

SP.SPEAKER: mo,
SP.P: Pox a Hippolita, I am a dumbe woman and you can tel me newes of Dorus

SP.SPEAKER: da,
SP.P: I had rather see ten doruses hangd then lose Hippolita,

SP.SPEAKER: mo,
SP.P: I had rather see ten fathers damd then lose my sweet dorus,

SP.SPEAKER: da,
SP.P: I shal run mad and I find not Hippolita.

SP.SPEAKER: Mop:
SP.P: I shall run franticke and I find not Dorus.

SP.SPEAKER: Dut:
SP.P: Whats heere, I shall run mad for Hipolita.

SP.SPEAKER: duke:
SP.P: And I shall run franticke and I find not Dorus, I hold my life we haue some comedy in hand, we shall haue a full sceane, for here comes more actors.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife
SP.P: Assures I am a sinner to God madam, that sames he.

SP.SPEAKER: muso
SP.P: What with a brace of wenches, I faith olde brocke, haue I tane you in the maner, is this the fruits of your lying alone? is this your court custome with a wanion, lend mee thy knife, tho I had neither house, nor land to giue em, ile bestow a whores make be∣twixt you and yet I will not scold neither.

SP.SPEAKER: mep:
SP.P: What a gudyere aile you mother, are you frampall, know you not your owne daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: miso.
SP.P: Mopsa, O insufferable wrong, make thine own natural child thy bawd,

SP.SPEAKER: duke
SP.P: Heeres an excellent patterne for wiues to learne to scold by

SP.SPEAKER: miso.
SP.P: What mistres Amason, ha you such a cocking spirit, honest Women cannot keepe their husbands at home for you: tis not for nothing now I see, that the Dutches lookes yellow on you, but ile teare that painted whores face of yours (by this light) and yet I wil not scold neither.

SP.SPEAKER: man
SP.P: Madam,

SP.SPEAKER: miso:
SP.P: ile mad you with a vengeance.

DIV3.STAGE: The duke and dutches step both forth and restraine her.

SP.SPEAKER: dut,
SP.P: Touch not the prince.

SP.SPEAKER: duke
SP.P: On your alleagance forbeare, what means this outrage, can∣not our private walks be priviledged from your wilde contentious.

SP.SPEAKER: dut:
SP.P: how fares the prince.

SP.SPEAKER: duk:
SP.P: How cheares my good Zelmane?

SP.SPEAKER: man:
SP.P: Zelmane, no Gods my iudge my liege, I am Manasses, mi∣serable Manasses, your husbands scribe-maor madam.

SP.SPEAKER: dut:
SP.P: Manasses.

SP.SPEAKER: duk:
SP.P: A foole.

SP.SPEAKER: mis.
SP.P: My man.

SP.SPEAKER: wife
SP.P: And my deere head, alas sweet loue, what makest thou heer.

SP.SPEAKER: m,
SP.P: Mary worke for the hangman, and the Duke be not the more mercifull.

SP.SPEAKER: duke
SP.P: Theres some deceit in this, Dametas, wheres Hippolita?

SP.SPEAKER: dam:
SP.P: I, I, theres som knauery in this: Mopso wheres Hippolita?

SP.SPEAKER: mis:
SP.P: doubtles theres some villany in this, Mepso whers Hipolita?

SP.SPEAKER: mep:
SP.P: Thers no plaine dealing in this, Manasses wheres Dorus?

SP.SPEAKER: Gry:
SP.P: Answere directly, wheres Hippolita?

SP.SPEAKER: dam:
SP.P: Alas madam I knowe not, whilst I almost melted my selfe with digging of gold in Dianaes oke, I left her in my wiues charge

SP.SPEAKER: wife
SP.P: And whilst I ran to Manasses, thinking to take my husband & his wife in the manner, I left Hipolita in my daughters chamber

SP.SPEAKER: man:
SP.P: and whilst I came to Adonis chappel to be tost in my mari∣age blankets with Dorus, I left my little dog pearl plucking dazies:

SP.SPEAKER: duke
SP.P: Who sent you to Diannes oke to dig gold?

SP.SPEAKER: Gry:
SP.P: who sent you to take your husband in Manasses house?

SP.SPEAKER: wife:
SP.P: dorus.

SP.SPEAKER: duke
SP.P: who sent you to Adonis chappell.

SP.SPEAKER: mep:
SP.P: dorus:

SP.SPEAKER: duke
SP.P: And who turnd you into this shape:

SP.SPEAKER: Man:
SP.P: They that I feare haue made guls of vs all, Zelmane, and dorus:

SP.SPEAKER: duke:
SP.P: we are all simply gulde, and see where the Sunne scarce halfeready, skippes from his Easterne bed, smiling at our gullery:

SP.SPEAKER: dem:
SP.P: Come wheres this lusty wit-maister.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa:
SP.P: the keeper of this loue-lottery,

SP.SPEAKER: dem:
SP.P: This gallant luventus of fourscore, that like my Lady of the Lake, displaies against al commers.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisan.
SP.P: May a couple of plaine witted princes haue a sight of your prizes:

SP.SPEAKER: dem:
SP.P: Where be these Ladies ha? ha your wits had such a skirmish¦ing that the two maides haue lost their heads in the conflict.

SP.SPEAKER: dut;
SP.P: Heads, I and bodyes to my Lorde, and all at one shot, and which is worse our wits are so scatered with the terible blow that to be plaine we are scarce our owne men againe.

SP.SPEAKER: dem:
SP.P: then you haue had some knockng,

SP.SPEAKER: mun:
SP.P: so it appeares by the storie my Lord:

SP.SPEAKER: lisan:
SP.P: How say yu my lady, what Oule sings out of that Iuy bush

SP.SPEAKER: dem:
SP.P: was your knighted in this last action:

SP.SPEAKER: man:
SP.P: I am ch a foole, I loue my lord, I am no knight, I am Manasses, they made a plaine foole.

SP.SPEAKER: Dam:
SP.P: the onely were, for the gaurded foole is out of request: but faith my liedge how did your opposites behaue themselues, did they win the Wenches faire at the point?

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.P: At the very push of inuention, and went off cleere vntoucht,

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa:
SP.P: And could you draw no blood of their wits:

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.P: Not a drop.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: Nor demetrius neither, nor Manasses?

SP.SPEAKER: Du:
SP.P: Neither, to our owne disgrace be it spoken, the carriage of their stratagem deserues applause, and I held it a credit to rest cap∣tiue to such valiant conquerors?

SP.SPEAKER: Lisan:
SP.P: Why so be, I like a man that wil confesse his error.

SP.SPEAKER: Da:
SP.P: It merrits comisseration madam and my liege, not to detract from our worth: your eare, we two are the parties you wot on.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.P: Ware you the men?

SP.SPEAKER: Lisan:
SP.P: No he was the man, mary I was the woman in the moone, that made you walk al this last night like the man in the mist, I could say somewhat to you to Madam as for demetrius & his man let them stand like fooles as they are.

SP.SPEAKER: Du.
SP.P: Can it be possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Da.
SP.P: No, no, we are guls, Innocent sots, but lante tanta, the girles are ours we haue won em away to dargison.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa:
SP.P: Come we haue won the conquest, and thats sufficient.

SP.SPEAKER: Da.
SP.P: You are a manasses tis not sufficient: aha not Hercules for iole, Ioue, for Danue, Apollo for daphene, pan for Sine, nay the whole pack of their piperly godheads could a dischargd a stratagem with more spirit of al merit, an ambling nag and a down a down we haue borne her away to dargison.

SP.SPEAKER: dut.
SP.P: Twas the most rarest, diuinest, Metaphisicalst, piece of inuention, that, what say you my leige.

SP.SPEAKER: Du:
SP.P: I giue your desarts their full merrit you haue gotten equality

SP.SPEAKER: iulio:
SP.P: All the wenches gaue you:

SP.SPEAKER: Da.
SP.P: Alas what spirits vnder the moone could haue detainder but know that her cherry red lip, a downe, a downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip:
SP.P: Trust me but you haue deserued high commendation.

SP.SPEAKER: iulio:
SP.P: Your merrit stood of the vpper staire of admiration.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem:
SP.P: Why thou hast a pretty relish of wit, now that canst see the broad ey of my desart at a little hole of demonstration.

SP.SPEAKER: iulo.
SP.P:
your desart saue me free, you haue done a most (to vse your own
phrase) Metaphysicall piece of seruice, but you had some helpe int questionles,

SP.SPEAKER: Hip:
SP.P: I do not thinke but the ladies had some hand int:

SP.SPEAKER: da,
SP.P: A finger, I confesse a finger by the hope of perseuerance, a very litle finger.

SP.SPEAKER: iuli,
SP.P: I thought asmuch by the making of the iest.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip,
SP.P: I can∣not detract from the ladies worth, for I knowem for excellent work women,

SP.SPEAKER: dam,
SP.P: work women fit to make tailors men.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip.
SP.P: I by my faith do I, nay your best tailors are arrant botchers to em, you shal haue a lady make an end of a sute, a court sute, espe∣cially when all the tailors in a countrey know not how to set a stich int.

SP.SPEAKER: dorus,
SP.P: Some ordinary sute perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: Hip:
SP.P: your best court suits that are, are finisht by ladies, I haue known a suit my selfe lien a making and maring 3, 4, and fiue yeare together and then a lady hath despacht it in a month with a wet finger, such a finger might the ladies haue in your plot.

SP.SPEAKER: de,
SP.P: neuer wet a finger by this sun.

SP.SPEAKER: iuli.
SP.P: Then she helpt you with one dry iest or other, but and we may be so bold: faith where are the ladies?

SP.SPEAKER: da.
SP.P: sure enogh I warrant you, some fooles now would haue kept em heare and haue beene guld on em againe, and laught at age, bvt to preuent all danger, we haue shipt em home for Lacedemon,

SP.SPEAKER: iulio:
SP.P: to Lacedemon, your sunne of wit shines but dimly in that methinkes, to whose charge haue you trusted em?

SP.SPEAKER: Lisan:
SP.P: to them we durst, nay you must thinke wee are no fooles,

SP.SPEAKER: iu.
SP.P: Fooles: nay deepe wit, and pollicy forbid.

SP.SPEAKER: Da,
SP.P: We had no sooner their surprisall, but we had disguise ready, a ship ready, a couple of lusty friends ready, the Lacedemons intel∣ligencers:

SP.SPEAKER: iuli.
SP.P: durst you trust such pretious iewels in such rusty cas∣kets:

SP.SPEAKER: da:
SP.P: durst, our health, our liues: why they were my tenants, nay you must thinke we sifted them, we are no fooles in that neither.

SP.SPEAKER: hip:
SP.P: If in any thing your wits deserue the bable tis in that,

SP.SPEAKER: iuli:
SP.P: none but fools wold haue commited such inestimable peeres to a couple of strangers:

SP.SPEAKER: hip:
SP.P: And in a ship to,

SP.SPEAKER: iu:
SP.P: And vnder saile to.

SP.SPEAKER: dut:
SP.P: And vnfurnisht of friends to.

SP.SPEAKER: du:
SP.P: And without shipping to follow em to.

SP.SPEAKER: iu.
SP.P: you were no fooles in any thing but that, & in that not to flatter, you expresse the true shape of folly and merely merrit the name of fools.

SP.SPEAKER: da.
SP.P: What will you saie now when these fellowes surrender vs our loues?

SP.SPEAKER: Aunt
SP.P: Weele discharge you and set their names down for gulls in your stead.

SP.SPEAKER: De:
SP.P: you know the prouerbe when the skie fals we shal haue larks.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisan:
SP.P: And when you can bring proofe that we are cosend of our Wenches weele be the woodcocks.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio:
SP.P: Why then we haue once springed a couple of woodcockes.

SP.SPEAKER: Aunt:
SP.P: Doe you know these? Who are the fooles now?

SP.SPEAKER: deme:
SP.P: Violletta.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisand:
SP.P: My Hippolita:

SP.SPEAKER: dam:
SP.P: What a strange change is heere:

SP.SPEAKER: Hippo:
SP.P: yes faith gallants you haue very strange carding and you knew al, but I hope youle offer vp your cards and yeild the set lost.

SP.SPEAKER: dam:
SP.P: Guls:

SP.SPEAKER: Lisan:
SP.P: And abusd ile loose my life before I loose my honor,

SP.SPEAKER: dam.
SP.P: Honor, and life before ile loose my loue:

SP.SPEAKER: Du:
SP.P: Nay gentlemen we bar all violence, the liberty of our chal∣lenge was to all alike equally free, and since these by faire play haue won em, it stands with our honor to see them peaceably possest of em, then surely take em, for though you weare the breeches giue vs leaue to stand a little:

SP.SPEAKER: Hippo:
SP.L: why father ist not time that we were sped
Tis a great charge to keepe a maidenhead,
Loose it we must and to preuent il course,
Better to giuet then haue it stolne perforce,
if you be pleasd let enuy doe her worst
Spit out her poyson or containt and burst?
Welcome to all, to all a kind god night,
They trewly liue, that liue in scorne of spight.

DIV1.P: In B. the last page, for Lord, read loue cannot be saued.
